text: Cornelius James Doyle (December 6, 1871 - April 29, 1938) was an American lawyer and politician. Born in Carlinville, Illinois, Doyle moved to Greenfield, Illinois with his family and went to the Greenfield public schools. He learned to become a tailor and worked as a clerk in a clothing store in Carlinville. Doyle then studied law and was admitted to the Illinois bar. He served as Greenfield city attorney and was involved with the Republican Party. He served as the Illinois Parole Commissioner and as secretary of the Illinois Board of Arbitration. In 1903, Doyle served as the superintendent of the Illinois Building of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition. In 1912, Doyle was appointed Illinois Secretary of State when the incumbent James A. Rose died in office. He was defeated for re-election in the November 1912 general election. Doyle died at a hospital in Springfield, Illinois from complications from surgery for appendicitis.'Past and Present of Greene County, Illinois,' Ed Miner-editor,' S. J. Clarke Publishing Company, Chicago, Illinois: 1905, Biographical Sketch of Cornelius James Doyle, pg. 369-370'Ex- State Secretary Cornelius Doyle, Dies,' Centralia Evening Sentinel, April 30, 1938, pg. 9 ==Notes== ==External links== * Category:1871 births Category:1938 deaths Category:People from Greenfield, Illinois Category:People from Carlinville, Illinois Category:Illinois lawyers Category:Tailors Category:Illinois Republicans Category:Secretaries of State of Illinois
title: Cornelius J. Doyle
